1.text:
In hot, sunny weather, keeping plants in
containers watered

5.text: can take a considerable amount of time.

7.text:
Then there's always the anxiety about
how plants will fare

10.text:
when you're away for a
well-earned break.

12.text:
One solution is to use self-watering
pots, such as this.

16.text:
It's actually very easy and inexpensive
to make one,

20.text: so in this video we'll show you how - step-by-step.

23.text:
You'll need two containers which, when stacked,
will leave a gap between the bottom and top containers.

29.text: The gap will serve as your water reservoir.

31.text:
If there isn't enough of a gap you can
use some plastic pots

34.text: to raise the top container up a little more.

37.text:
We're using two 5-gallon (20 liter)
food-grade plastic buckets.

41.text:
You can often pick these up for free from restaurants, 
or very cheaply from home improvement stores.

46.text:
You'll also need a one and a half inch (3cm)
diameter plastic pipe

50.text:
long enough to run the length of the two
buckets,

53.text: a plastic cup, yogurt pot or similar to act as a wicking chamber

57.text:
and of course some quality potting soil
and your plants.

61.text:
Start by preparing the
wicking chamber.

64.text:
This should dangle down from the top
bucket into the bottom.

67.text:
Stuffed with potting soil, it will draw or wick water
from the reservoir up into the top bucket.

73.text:
Use a marker pen to trace an outline
of the pot onto the middle of the top bucket.

79.text:
You can use a keyhole saw
or a hacksaw for this.

82.text:
Here I'm using a drill to make lots of small holes so I
can use a sharp knife to cut the plastic out.

88.text:
The wicking chamber will need lots
of holes all over the sides

91.text: to allow the water to enter from the reservoir.

93.text: Use a half-inch (1cm) wide drill bit to make these.

98.text:
Now for the water delivery
pipe.

100.text: Begin by cutting one end of your plastic pipe at a 45-degree angle like this.

105.text:
This will allow the water to freely flow
from the pipe into the reservoir without getting blocked.

110.text:
Cut the top end so it
stands clear of the final soil level.

114.text:
Now cut a hole into the bottom of the
top bucket so the pipe can pass into the reservoir.

119.text:
Make sure it's snug fit by
tracing the outline then cutting to size.

125.text:
The top bucket will need some drainage
holes for healthy root growth.

128.text:
Drill lots of quarter-inch or 5mm holes
into its base.

132.text:
You can go for a random pattern or an
orderly effects such as this.

137.text:
Stack the top bucket into the bottom bucket, then
mark off using a pen where the top buckets sits.

143.text:
Remove the top bucket and drill a quarter-inch (5mm)
hole into the bottom bucket just below this line.

150.text: This will serve as an overflow hole, so the potting soil in the top bucket never gets waterlogged.

155.text:
It also removes any guesswork from
filling the reservoir -

159.text:
just stop when the water starts to drain
out from the overflow.

163.text: Now it's time to assemble the container.

165.text:
Insert the top bucket into the bottom
bucket.

168.text: Fill the wicking chamber with potting soil, firming it in for good contact,

172.text:
then slot the chamber snugly into its
hole.

175.text: Slide the water delivery pipe into place, pointy end down.

180.text:
Fill the top bucket with
potting soil, moistening with water as you fill.

184.text:
You can plant several plants into the top bucket
according to their spacing requirements,

189.text:
or set one plant such as a tomato at
the center.

193.text:
This allows you to cover up the
remaining soil surface, which will reduce evaporation -

200.text: Use a lid for this, cutting appropriate holes to accommodate the plant and the pipe.

205.text: Alternatively you can use a thick garbage bag,

208.text: secured at the sides with rubber bands, a bungee cord, or string.

212.text:
You could also add a shallow ring of
organic fertilizer around the plant.

216.text:
The moist potting soil will gradually draw
the nutrients down into the soil to feed the plant's roots.

222.text:
This is a fantastically elegant solution
to daily watering,

227.text: and you can always add additional self-watering containers as time allows.

231.text:
Please share your tips for self-watering
plants by just dropping us a comment below,

236.text:
and for more practical projects such as this, 
make sure you're subscribed to our video channel.
